author: ajsutton
content: Teku had no issues with eth1.  It’s very hard to get it exactly right and we went through a lot of different approaches before settling on our current one which avoids trying to do anything clever and seems to work really well.

author: ajsutton
content:
One thing that will be interesting is that the move to MainNet will mean moving to variable block times whereas göerli is pretty consistently 15 seconds. 

For clients that are trying to guess block ranges based on the seconds per eth1 block constant, they’ll want to leave a lot of tolerance on MainNet.

author: ajsutton
content: But the plus side is that it doesn’t cause a chain split and the worst case is that deposits are delayed. It’s not ideal but it’s not the end of the world either.

author: ajsutton
content:
Görli uses clique so has fixed 15 second block times. MainNet blocks appear whenever the POW solution is found so vary a lot (but average to between 13 and 17 seconds because of the way the difficulty adjustment happens). Currently and for quite a while, MainNet has been at the low end of that averaging 13-14 seconds. 

On the scale of an eth1 voting period it likely averages out quite well. Just clients can’t assume that the blocks will be evenly spaced.

author: ajsutton
content: I’m not expecting major issues with eth1 even with the change to block times on MainNet but it’s complex enough that I’m sure some tweaks will be needed.
